title: Replace autogenerated docs with redirect to current schema docs
body:
Re: https://github.com/microbiomedata/issues/issues/83. Basically we have at least one publication out there with links in it to https://microbiomedata.github.io/nmdc-metadata/. There are two issues: first, that URL currently doesn't resolve to anything because GitHub made private repos (such as this one) ineligible for hosting GitHub Pages sites. Second, if we simply made this repo public again, the `gh-pages` branch currently holds a bunch of old, outdated auto-generated schema docs.

These changes replace the old, outdated auto-generated schema docs in the `gh-pages` branch with an HTML-file redirect to https://microbiomedata.github.io/nmdc-schema/. 

Once these changes are merged two things need to happen:

* A repo admin needs to make this repo public again (or give me admin privileges to do the same)
* I will go into the `main` branch and remove the workflow file that publishes to GitHub Pages so that the redirect isn't accidentally overwritten if someone happens to push changes to this repo in the future

comments.body: This will take a bit of discussion. I dont think that are properties like id and name belong in prov.

Sure. You recently [added id and name to prov](https://github.com/microbiomedata/nmdc-metadata/commit/c760c6ff4c5e5d676ce0f4234238298e1ade3c6d), but I guess this was intended as temporary? I'm fine with id and name not being in prov -- it makes sense for prov to merely subset terms of <http://www.w3.org/ns/prov#> and not add anything else.

so what I did was add these as class slots to the classes in prov, the
fields are still defined in core

this is suboptimal for a modularization point of view as we have a
reciprical dependency between prov and core. this is harmless so long as
you are using the root of the import chain (nmdc), which is what we care
about... but if you want to work with prov as a separate unit then you
don't have the fields declared and you get errors as you discovered

tl;dr - not a big issue for now but we can fix later with better
modulatization!

  data object:

      Subset consisting of the data objects that either inputs or outputs of processes or workflows.
```

title: test biolinkml 1.5.4
body:
I updated to biolinkml `1.5.4` and ran `make all`. In the `nmdc.py` file, we now have slots of the for <x value>_has_raw_ value, <x value>_has_unit, etc. For example:
```
slots.quantity_value_has_raw_value = Slot(uri=NMDC.has_raw_value, name="quantity value_has raw value", curie=NMDC.curie('has_raw_value'),
                      model_uri=NMDC.quantity_value_has_raw_value, domain=QuantityValue, range=Optional[str])

slots.quantity_value_has_unit = Slot(uri=NMDC.has_unit, name="quantity value_has unit", curie=NMDC.curie('has_unit'),
                      model_uri=NMDC.quantity_value_has_unit, domain=QuantityValue, range=Optional[str])

slots.quantity_value_has_numeric_value = Slot(uri=NMDC.has_numeric_value, name="quantity value_has numeric value", curie=NMDC.curie('has_numeric_value'),
                      model_uri=NMDC.quantity_value_has_numeric_value, domain=QuantityValue, range=Optional[float])

slots.person_value_has_raw_value = Slot(uri=NMDC.has_raw_value, name="person value_has raw value", curie=NMDC.curie('has_raw_value'),
                      model_uri=NMDC.person_value_has_raw_value, domain=PersonValue, range=Optional[str])

slots.geolocation_value_has_raw_value = Slot(uri=NMDC.has_raw_value, name="geolocation value_has raw value", curie=NMDC.curie('has_raw_value'),
                      model_uri=NMDC.geolocation_value_has_raw_value, domain=GeolocationValue, range=Optional[str])

```
The good news is that the owl file is now built, but the aforementioned slots create object properties like in the screenshot below.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3186638/89944346-a3cbdc80-dbed-11ea-9024-71a5e135741a.png)

title: test biolinkml 1.5.3
body:
Re-ran the ETL codes using biolinkml 1.5.3. Before running, I made a copy of nmdc database named  `nmdc_database_1.json`. After running, I compared the MD5 checksums of `nmdc_database_1.json`, the newly created `nmdc_database.json`, and the `nmdc_database.json` on the master branch. Here is the summary:
```
MD5 (nmdc_database_1.json) = d555079dd496690bd754d02811898a71
  MD5 (nmdc_database.json) = d555079dd496690bd754d02811898a71
  MD5 (nmdc_database.json) = d555079dd496690bd754d02811898a71 ** copy on master branch
```
All three checksums match. 

Also recreated the `nmdc.py` file using `make clean` followed by `make all`.

This gives me confidence that the new version of biolinkml did not break our site.

{'has_raw_value': 'Terrestrial'}: {'has_raw_value': 'Terrestrial'} is not of type 'string'
{'has_raw_value': 'Wetlands'}: {'has_raw_value': 'Wetlands'} is not of type 'string'
{'has_raw_value': 'Soil'}: {'has_raw_value': 'Soil'} is not of type 'string'
{'has_raw_value': 'Permafrost'}: {'has_raw_value': 'Permafrost'} is not of type 'string'
```
Can we add `{'has_raw_value': string}' as a valid schema?

title: Issue 42
body:
1. Sequencing project has been changed to omics processing.
2. Each omics processing object has a "processing_institution" annotation.
3. Each omics processing object has a "omics_type" annotation.
3. Each omics processing object has a "has_output" annotation that contains a list of file ids that identify the data objects  created by the omics processing. In many cases, this is a one to many relationship.
4. Each data object has an id (its file id), name, description, and file size annotation.

title: DO NOT MERGE: model properties directly in schema
body:
on master we have a generic annotation model, where properties such as depth, moisture, etc are treated as controlled terms outside the schema

E.g

```
sample1
  anns:
   - characteristic: {name: depth, id: mixs:nnn}
      value: 2cm
   ...
     
```

this PR treats the fields as part of the schema e.g

```
sample 1:
  depth: ...
  material: ...
```

Note the implications of merging this PR. Rather than having the fields live outside the schema (and be determined by some separate json or rdf that would ultimately come from gsc/mixs-ng) the fields would be determined by the schema. This would necessitate either:

 - periodic synchronization (semi-automatic?) between nmdc schema and mixs-ng efforts?
 - tighter coupling, and having one master file for the schema and the field definitions. For example, this could take the form of biolinkml managed in mixs-ng
